Abstract: This study presents advancements in 3D Lagrangian particle tracking techniques for fluid mechanics applications. We focus on the development and implementation of iterative particle reconstruction methods, with particular emphasis on the Shake-The-Box algorithm. The research explores the extraction of one- and multipoint statistics from particle trajectories, enabling the calculation of velocity gradient tensors and 3D pressure fields. We demonstrate the effectiveness of these techniques in capturing complex flow structures and turbulence characteristics. Additionally, we investigate the integration of particle tracking data with data assimilation methods to enhance the accuracy and resolution of flow field measurements. The proposed approach shows significant improvements in spatial and temporal resolution compared to traditional particle image velocimetry techniques. Our findings contribute to the understanding of fluid dynamics in various applications, including turbulence research, aerodynamics, and environmental flows, paving the way for more accurate and comprehensive flow field analysis.
